Title: Portrait of a Ruler
Medium: ink and pigments on paper mounted on pasteboard
Description: The rich purple robe, brocaded sash, pearls, and emeralds that this figure wears proclaim his elite status. His plumed headdress and the nimbus that surrounds his profile mark him as a ruler. Holding a flower and resting against an orange bolster, he sits in leisure. While the trees behind him suggest a garden setting, the artist has painted the surroundings rather sparsely, focusing attention on the ruler. The dramatic, impressionistic sky suggests the paintingâ€™s origin in the Deccan (a region in south-central India), probably in or around the city of Hyderabad.
CreditLine: Gift of John and Berthe Ford, 2001
Keywords: Indian; Islamic; Illustration; Miniature; Painting; India
Provenance: John and Berthe Ford, Baltimore [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Walters Art Museum, 2001, by gift.
Creator: Indian
